revision.text:
{{Infobox military unit |unit_name=Cameronians (Scottish Rifles) |image=[[Image:Cameronians.gif]] |caption=Cap Badge of the Cameronians (Scottish Rifles) |dates=1 July 1881 – 14 May 1968 |country={{flag|United Kingdom}} |branch={{army|United Kingdom}} |type=[[Rifle regiment|Rifles]] |command_structure=[[Lowland Brigade (United Kingdom)|Lowland Brigade]] |role= |size= 2 [[Regular army|Regular]] battalions
2 [[Militia (United Kingdom)|Militia]] battalions
2 - 4 [[Territorial Force|Territorial]] and [[Volunteer Force (Great Britain)|Volunteer]] battalions
Up to 12 hostilities-only battalions |current_commander= |garrison=[[Hamilton Barracks]], [[Hamilton, South Lanarkshire|Hamilton]] (1881–1947)
[[Winston Barracks]], [[Lanark]] (1947–1968) |ceremonial_chief=[[Gustaf VI Adolf of Sweden|HM King Gustaf VI Adolf]] |ceremonial_chief_label=Colonel in Chief |colonel_of_the_regiment= Major General Henry Templar Alexander, CB CBE DSO |nickname= (from the 1960's) The Poison Dwarfs. Not a popular nickname as it was derogatory. |colors= |identification_symbol_2= [[File:Douglastartan.jpg|The Douglas tartan|120px]] |identification_symbol_2_label=Tartan |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label= |march=Quick – ''Within a mile of Edinburgh Toon''
Slow – ''The Garb of Old Gaul'' |mascot= |battles= |notable_commanders= |anniversaries= }} The '''Cameronians (Scottish Rifles)''' was a [[Rifle regiment|rifle]] [[regiment]] of the [[British Army]], the only regiment of rifles amongst the [[Scottish regiment|Scottish]] regiments of infantry. It was formed in 1881 under the [[Childers Reforms]] by the amalgamation of the [[26th (Cameronian) Regiment of Foot|26th Cameronian Regiment]] and the [[90th Regiment of Foot (Perthshire Volunteers)|90th Perthshire Light Infantry]]. In 1968, when reductions were required, the regiment was the only regiment that decided to disband rather than amalgamate with another regiment. It can trace its roots to that of the Cameronians, later the 26th of Foot, who were raised in 1689. The 1881 amalgamation coincided with the Cameronian's selection to become the new Scottish Rifles. [[File:Spioenkop-British Memorial-Face5.jpg|thumb|Memorial on [[Spion Kop (mountain)|Spion Kop]]]] [[File:1st Battalion Cameronians (scottish Rifles) on the Western Front, 1914 - 1915 Q51587.jpg|thumb|1st Battalion Cameronians (Scottish Rifles) on the Western Front, 1914 - 1915]] [[File:Glasgow, Scottish Rifles memorial - geograph.org.uk - 1539610.jpg|thumb|The [[Cameronians War Memorial]] in [[Kelvingrove Park]]]] [[File:Cameronians Memorial plaque.JPG|thumb|Cameronians Memorial at [[Douglas, South Lanarkshire]]]] ==History== The Cameronians (Scottish Rifles) was formed in 1881 under the [[Childers Reforms]] by the amalgamation of the [[26th (Cameronian) Regiment of Foot|26th Cameronian Regiment]] and the [[90th Regiment of Foot (Perthshire Volunteers)|90th Perthshire Light Infantry]].{{cite web|url=http://www.regiments.org/regiments/uk/inf/026Camer.htm |title=The Cameronians (Scottish Rifles) |publisher=Regiments.org |accessdate=11 June 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051230130626/http://www.regiments.org/regiments/uk/inf/026Camer.htm |archivedate=December 30, 2005 }} After the amalgamation, the 1st Battalion preferred to be known as "The Cameronians" while the 2nd preferred to be known as "The Scottish Rifles". The 2nd Battalion saw action at the [[Battle of Spion Kop]] in January 1900 during the [[Second Boer War]].{{cite web|url=http://www.angloboerwar.com/unit-information/imperial-units/660-cameronians-scottish-rifles|title=Cameronians (Scottish Rifles)|publisher=Anglo-Boer War|accessdate=11 June 2016}} A 3rd, [[Militia (United Kingdom)|Militia]] battalion (formerly the 2nd Royal Lanark Militia), was embodied in May 1900 for service during the Second Boer War. More than 600 men embarked for [[South Africa]] in April 1901, and returned in June 1902, following the end of hostilities.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The Army in South Africa - The return of the Troops |day_of_week=Wednesday |date=2 July 1902 |page_number=11 |issue=36809}} ==First World War== ===Regular Army=== The 1st Battalion landed at [[Le Havre]] as part of the [[19th Light Brigade (United Kingdom)|19th Brigade]], which was an independent command at that time, in August 1914 for service on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]].{{cite web|url=http://www.longlongtrail.co.uk/army/regiments-and-corps/the-british-infantry-regiments-of-1914-1918/cameronians-scottish-rifles/|title= Cameronians (Scottish Rifles)|publisher=The Long, Long Trail|accessdate=12 June 2016}} The battalion famously refused to play football or otherwise fraternise with the enemy on [[Christmas|Christmas Day]] 1914.{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/topics/christmas/10534047/Scottish-Rifles-the-soldiers-who-refused-to-play-ball-at-Christmas-during-First-World-War.html|title=Scottish Rifles - the soldiers who refused to play ball at Christmas during First World War|publisher=The Telegraph|date=22 December 2013|accessdate=11 June 2016}} The 2nd Battalion landed in France as part of the [[23rd Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|23rd Brigade]] in the [[8th Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|8th Division]] in November 1914 for service on the Western Front. ===Territorial Force=== The 1/5th Battalion landed at Le Havre as part of the 19th Brigade in the [[6th Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|6th Division]] in November 1915 for service on the Western Front. The 1/6th Battalion landed at Le Havre as part of the 23rd Brigade in the 8th Division in March 1915 for service on the Western Front. The 1/7th Battalion and the 1/8th Battalion landed in [[Gallipoli]] as part of the [[156th (Scottish Rifles) Brigade|156th Brigade]] in the [[52nd (Lowland) Infantry Division|52nd (Lowland) Division]] in June 1915; after evacuation from Gallipoli in January 1916 the battalions moved to Egypt and then landed at [[Marseille]] in April 1918 for service on the Western Front. ===New Armies=== The 9th (Service) Battalion landed at [[Boulogne-sur-Mer]] as part of the [[27th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|27th Brigade]] in the [[9th (Scottish) Division]] in May 1915 for service on the Western Front. The 10th (Service) Battalion landed at Boulogne-sur-Mer as part of the [[46th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|46th Brigade]] in the [[15th (Scottish) Infantry Division|15th (Scottish) Division]] in July 1915 for service on the Western Front. The 11th (Service) Battalion landed at Boulogne-sur-Mer as part of the 77th Brigade in the [[26th Division (United Kingdom)|26th Division]] in September 1915 for service on the Western Front but sailed for [[Thessaloniki|Salonika]] in November 1915. ==Inter-war== The 1st Battalion was deployed to Ireland in 1919 during the [[Irish War of Independence]] and then went to India in 1931 while the 2nd Battalion was deployed to [[Mesopotamia]] in 1919 and then went to India in 1922.{{cite web|url=http://www.nam.ac.uk/research/famous-units/cameronians-scottish-rifles|title=Cameronians (Scottish Rifles)|publisher=National Army Museum|accessdate=11 June 2016}} ==Second World War== The 1st Battalion, which had been in [[British Raj|India]] at the start of the war, was deployed to [[Myanmar|Burma]] as part of the [[1st Burma Infantry Brigade|1st Burma Brigade]] in the [[39th Infantry Division (India)|39th Indian Division]] in 1942 and saw action in the [[Burma Campaign]].{{cite web|url=http://www.burmastar.org.uk/stories/1st-burma-division/|title=1st Burma Division|publisher=Burma Star Association|accessdate=11 June 2016}} [[File:The British Army in Italy 1943 NA8975.jpg|thumb|right|Infantrymen of the 2nd Battalion, Cameronians climbing a track in mountainous terrain, 21 November 1943.]] The 2nd Battalion was deployed to France as part of the [[13th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|13th Infantry Brigade]] in the [[5th Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|5th Division]] within the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War II)|British Expeditionary Force]] (BEF) in September 1939 and, after taking part in the [[Dunkirk evacuation]] in June 1940, saw action in the [[Allied invasion of Sicily]] in July 1943 and the [[Allied invasion of Italy]] in September 1943 and, after fighting in the [[Italian Campaign (World War II)|Italian Campaign]], serving in both the [[Moro River Campaign|Moro River]] and [[Battle of Anzio|Anzio campaign]]s until July 1944, took part in the [[North West Europe Campaign]] in early 1945, ending in May.{{cite web|url=http://www.wartimememoriesproject.com/ww2/allied/battalion.php?pid=866|title=2nd Battalion Cameronians (Scottish Rifles)|publisher=Wartime Memories Project|accessdate=11 June 2016}} The 6th and 7th Battalions, both [[Army Reserve (United Kingdom)|Territorial Army]] battalions, were deployed to France as part of the [[156th (Scottish Rifles) Brigade|156th Infantry Brigade]] in the [[52nd (Lowland) Infantry Division]] to provide cover for the withdrawal of troops of the British Expeditionary Force; after the [[Normandy landings]] in June 1944, the battalion took part in the North West Europe Campaign in late 1944 and in 1945.{{cite web|url=http://www.wartimememoriesproject.com/ww2/allied/battalion.php?pid=867|title=6th Battalion Cameronians (Scottish Rifles)|publisher=Wartime Memories Project|accessdate=11 June 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wartimememoriesproject.com/ww2/allied/battalion.php?pid=868|title=7th Battalion Cameronians (Scottish Rifles)|publisher=Wartime Memories Project|accessdate=11 June 2016}} The 9th Battalion took part in the Normandy landings as part of the [[46th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|46th (Highland) Infantry Brigade]] in the [[15th (Scottish) Infantry Division]] in June 1944 and saw action in the North West Europe Campaign in late 1944 and in 1945.{{cite web|url=http://www.wartimememoriesproject.com/ww2/allied/battalion.php?pid=869|title=9th Battalion Cameronians (Scottish Rifles)|publisher=Wartime Memories Project|accessdate=11 June 2016}} ==Post-war== In 1948, along with every other infantry regiment of the British Army, the Cameronians was reduced to a single regular battalion. The 1st Battalion which had been repeatedly decimated in the Burma campaign was placed in suspended animation and the 2nd Battalion was renamed the 1st. It was deployed to [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]] in 1950 during the [[Malayan Emergency]].{{cite web|url=http://cameronians.siteiscentral.com/1901/campaigns/malaya|title=Malayan Emergency 1948-1960|publisher=Cameronians|accessdate=12 June 2016}} Under the reforms of the army in the [[1967 Defence White Paper]], which saw several regiments amalgamated, the Cameronians chose to disband rather than amalgamate with another in the [[Lowland Brigade (United Kingdom)|Lowland Brigade]]. The 1st Battalion, The Cameronians was disbanded on 14 May 1968 at [[Douglas Castle]], near [[Douglas, South Lanarkshire|Douglas]], [[South Lanarkshire]] in the presence of the [[Douglas Douglas-Hamilton, 14th Duke of Hamilton|Duke of Hamilton]], the Earl of Angus. Its recruiting area in [[Lanarkshire]] and [[Dumfries and Galloway]] taken over by the [[King's Own Scottish Borderers]] and the Regimental Headquarters finally closed in 1987. ==Traditions== Every new member of the regiment was issued a [[Bible]], as a nod to [[Richard Cameron (Covenanter)|Richard Cameron]], after whom the original 26th Foot was named and the regiment mounted an armed guard at the doors of the [[Kirk]] during religious services.{{cite web|url=http://www.cameronians.org/lanarkshire-connections/index.html|title=Lanarkshire connections|publisher=Cameronians|accessdate=12 June 2016}} Soldiers wore a rifle green [[Doublet (clothing)|doublet]] with [[Clan Douglas|Douglas]] tartan [[trews]] as part of their full dress and No.1 dress uniforms.{{cite web|url=http://www.cameronians.siteiscentral.com/glossary/doublet|title=Doublet|publisher=Cameronians|accessdate=11 June 2016}} ==Battle honours== The regiment's battle honours included: *''Early wars'': Blenheim, Ramillies, Oudenarde, Malplaquet, South Africa 1846-72, South Africa 1877-8-92, Relief of Ladysmith, South Africa 1899-1902 *''The Great War'': Mons, Le Cateau, Retreat from Mons, Marne 1914 '18, Aisne 1914, La Bassée 1914, Messines 1914, Armentières 1914, Neuve Chapelle, Aubers, Loos, Somme 1916 '18, Albert 1916, Bazentin, Pozières, Flers-Courcelette, Le Transloy, Ancre Heights, Arras 1917 '18, Scarpe 1917 '18, Arleux, Ypres 1917 '18, Pilckem, Langemarck 1917, Menin Road, Polygon Wood, Passchendaele, St Quentin, Rosières, Avre, Lys, Hazebrouck, Bailleul, Kemmel, Scherpenberg, Soissonnais-Ourcq, Drocourt-Quéant, Hindenberg Line, Épéhy, Canal du Nord, St Quentin Canal, Cambrai 1918, Courtrai, Selle, Sambre, France and Flanders 1914-18, Doiran 1917 '18, Macedonia 1915-18, Gallipoli 1915-16, Rumani, Egypt 1916-17, Gaza, El Mughar, Nebi Samwil, Jaffa, Palestine 1917-18 *''Second World War'': Ypres-Comines Canal, Odon, Cheux, Caen, Mont Pincon, Estry, Nederrijn, Best, Scheldt, South Beveland, Walcheren Causeway, Asten, Roer, Rhineland, Reichswald, Moyland, Rhine, Dreirwalde, Bremen, Artlenberg, North-West Europe 1940, '44-45, Landing in Sicily, Simeto Bridgehead, Sicily 1943, Garigliano Crossing, Anzio, Advance to Tiber, Italy 1943-44, Pegu 1942, Paungde, Yenagyaung 1942, Chindits 1944, Burma 1942 '44 ==Affiliations== Affiliations included: * {{CAN}} [[The Perth Regiment]] – 1965: [[Canada]] * {{AUS}} [[26th Battalion (Australia)|26th Battalion (The Logan and Albert Regiment)]] 1928 – 1951: [[Australia]] * {{NZ}} [[Otago and Southland Regiment|The Otago and Southland Regiment]] 1948 – 1968: [[New Zealand]] * {{RSA}} [[Witwatersrand Rifles Regiment|The Witwatersrand Rifles]] 1937 – 1961: [[South Africa]] * {{GHA}} 2nd Battalion, [[Ghana Regiment]]: [[Ghana]] * {{UK}} [[7th Duke of Edinburgh's Own Gurkha Rifles]] 1951– 1968: United Kingdom ==Notable former members of the regiment== * See also [[:Category:Cameronians officers]] and [[:Category:Cameronians soldiers]] * General [[Roy Bucher|Sir Roy Bucher]] * General [[Horatius Murray|Sir Horatius Murray]] * General [[Richard O'Connor]] * General [[Thomas Riddell-Webster|Sir Thomas Riddell-Webster]] * Lieutenant-General [[George Collingwood|Sir George Collingwood]] * Lieutenant-General [[John Fullerton Evetts|Sir John Fullerton Evetts]] * Lieutenant-General [[Alexander Galloway|Sir Alexander Galloway]] * Major-General [[Henry Templer Alexander]] * Major-General [[George Carter-Campbell]] * Major-General [[John Frost (British Army officer)|John Dutton Frost]] * Major-General [[Douglas Alexander Graham|Douglas Graham]] * Major-General James Haugh{{cite web|url=http://www.sllcmuseumscollections.co.uk/search.do;jsessionid=aFRDq7EjpQz5Fvod--pxiMHw?db=object&sort=NAME&bool-3=AND&page=1222&field-3=USER_SYM_13&collection=0&view=detail&value-3=Written%2C+Printed+and+Digital+Collections+--+Military+History+--+Cameronians+(Scottish+Rifles)+Archive|title=Invitation to Major-General Haugh|publisher=South Lanarkshire Museum|accessdate=2 August 2016}} * Major-General Robin Money{{cite web|url=http://www.historylinks.org.uk/WW1%20Photos.htm|title=World War 1 Photographs|publisher=History Links Museum|accessdate=2 August 2016}} * Major-General [[Philip Robertson (British Army officer)|Sir Philip Rynd Robertson]] * Major-General Eric Sixsmith{{LondonGazette|issue=37598|supp=yes|startpage=2768|date=13 June 1946|accessdate=2 August 2016}} Also His Majesty [[Qaboos bin Said al Said|Sultan Qaboos]], the ruler of the Sultantate of [[Oman]], served with the Cameronians as a junior officer.Allen, p. 28–29, 34 ==The Cameronians Museum== The Cameronians Museum is located within the [[Hamilton Low Parks Museum|Low Parks Museum]], [[Hamilton, South Lanarkshire]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cameronians.org/museum/index.html|title=The Cameronians (Scottish Rifles) Collection - Low Parks Museum, Hamilton, Lanarkshire|accessdate=12 June 2016}} ==Memorials== Face 5 of the British memorial on [[Spion Kop (mountain)|Spion Kop]] lists the names of the soldiers from the Cameronians who died at the [[Battle of Spion Kop]] during the [[Second Boer War]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/photo/the-british-war-memorial-and-graveyard-at-high-res-stock-photography/506833703|title=The British War Memorial and graveyard at the Battle of Spion Kop|publisher=Getty images|accessdate=12 June 2016}} The [[Cameronians War Memorial]] in [[Kelvingrove Park]], [[Glasgow]] by [[Philip Lindsey Clark]], unveiled on 9 August 1924, depicts men of the regiment manning a [[Lewis gun]].{{cite web|url=http://www.glasgowsculpture.com/pg_images.php?sub=cameronians |title=Cameronians (Scottish Rifles) War Memorial|publisher=Scottish Sculpture|accessdate=12 June 2016}} A monument commemorating both the founding of the regiment by the [[James Douglas, Earl of Angus|Earl of Angus]] in 1689 and its disbanding in 1968 can be found at [[Douglas, South Lanarkshire]].{{cite web|url=https://www.visitscotland.com/info/see-do/cameronians-regimental-memorial-p254451|title=Cameronians's Regimental Memorial|publisher=Visit Scotland|accessdate=12 June 2016}} Also within the village is a statue of the Earl of Angus to commemorate the bicentenary of the raising of the regiment.{{cite web|url=http://www.community-council.org.uk:80/Douglas/index.asp?pageid=81 |title=Cameronian Scottish Rifles 1689 - 1968, Presentation to Douglas Heritage Museum, June 2006 |publisher=Douglas Community Council |accessdate=12 June 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060912084216/http://www.community-council.org.uk/Douglas/index.asp?pageid=81 |archivedate=September 12, 2006 }} ==References== {{Research help|Mil}} {{Reflist|2}} ==Sources== *{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f3pV457NIE4C|title=Oman Under Qaboos: From Coup to Constitution, 1970–1996|last=Allen|first=Calvin H.|last2=Rigsbee|first2=W. Lynn|date=2000-01-01|publisher=Psychology Press|year=|isbn=9780714650012}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Cameronians (Scottish Rifles)}} * [http://www.cameronians.org/index.html The Cameronians] * {{cite book|title=1st Battalion Cameronians (Scottish Rifles) Disbandment Programme|url=https://archive.org/stream/ScottishRifles-DisbandmentProgram/Cameronians-FormOfParadeOrderOfServiceForCameroniansDisbandment#page/n1/mode/2up|year=1968}} {{British Infantry Regiments World War I}} [[Category:Infantry regiments of the British Army|Cameronians]] [[Category:Regiments of Scotland]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1881]] [[Category:House of Douglas and Angus|*]] [[Category:Regiments of the British Army in World War II]] [[Category:Regiments of the British Army in World War I]] [[Category:Military units and formations disestablished in 1968]] [[Category:1881 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Rifle regiments]] [[Category:Military units and formations in Lanarkshire]] [[Category:Military units and formations in Burma in World War II|R]]
